title: 108_hr5403
content: The Act titled "Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004" aims to improve the quality of long term care in skilled nursing facilities under Medicare. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 requires skilled nursing facilities to provide detailed reporting of nursing expenditures, including wages and benefits for nursing staff by staff level. The Secretary will redesign cost reports to meet this requirement. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 mandates skilled nursing facilities to report nursing expenditures in detail. The Secretary will redesign cost reports to comply with this requirement and develop new quality measures in consultation with experts and stakeholders. The subsection mandates quality measures for nursing homes, including process, structural, and outcome measures that are valid, reliable, and minimize provider burden. It also requires at least one quality measure on nursing home staffing levels and makes special provisions for small facilities. The subsection mandates quality measures for nursing homes, including staffing levels, and makes special provisions for small facilities. The Secretary will post new quality performance measures on the Medicare program website. Amendments include linking payments to quality performance, maintaining fiscal year 2005 payment rates as a floor, and adjusting payments based on quality performance. The subsection mandates quality measures for nursing homes, including staffing levels, and makes special provisions for small facilities. The Secretary will post new quality performance measures on the Medicare program website. Amendments include linking payments to quality performance and maintaining fiscal year 2005 payment rates as a floor. The subsection requires quality measures for nursing homes, including staffing levels, with special provisions for small facilities. Payment under this title will be tied to performance on quality indicators, with a focus on direct care staffing. The Secretary will test new payment methods through pilot studies and demonstration projects. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the adequacy of Medicaid financing for quality nursing facility care, including compliance with State and Federal laws and regulations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on Medicaid financing for quality nursing facility care, Medicare's cross-subsidization, industry margins, trends impact, demographic changes, and options for financing long-term care. Annual reports on these activities will be submitted to Congress. The Secretary will submit annual reports to Congress on the amendments made to Medicaid financing for nursing facility care. A final report, due within 5 years, will include study results, impact on care quality, payment system recommendations, and analysis of alternative options. The final report will include study results, impact on care quality, payment system recommendations, and analysis of alternative options to address identified issues in skilled nursing facilities.
